issues.description: The problem statement and the template expect a public Farm.singFarmSong() method (used in the instructions and the template Main), but the solution implementation exposes a public method named playFarmSong() instead. This name mismatch means the solution does not provide the method students are told to implement and referenced in the template/Main. Students comparing solution and instructions (or trying to run the provided Main) would be confused or the code would not compile if tests or examples call singFarmSong().
issues.suggested_fix: Make the public method name consistent. Either rename the solution's playFarmSong() to singFarmSong(), or add a singFarmSong() method that delegates to playFarmSong(). Ensure the method name in the solution matches the one used in the problem statement, the template Main, and any tests.

issues.description: The template's private helper method singFarmSongVerse is declared without an Animal parameter (the parameter is commented out: singFarmSongVerse(/*Animal animal*/)), while both the problem UML and the solution implement singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal). This inconsistency in the method signature could confuse students about the intended helper API and makes the template's stub inconsistent with the described design.
issues.suggested_fix: Uncomment or add the Animal parameter in the template helper signature to match the UML and solution: private void singFarmSongVerse(Animal animal). This aligns the template with the intended design and avoids confusion about how to implement the verse printing.

issues.description: The problem statement and template expect a public Farm method named singFarmSong() (UML and Part 3 instructions explicitly refer to singFarmSong()). In the solution implementation the equivalent public method is named playFarmSong(), so the public API name for the same conceptual operation differs between template/problem and solution. This mismatch breaks the direct mapping students expect (and the template’s commented example calls farm.singFarmSong()), can cause confusion about which method to implement/invoke, and will make automated tests or instructor checks that call singFarmSong() fail against the solution as provided.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the public API name in the solution with the problem/template by renaming the solution method playFarmSong() to singFarmSong(), or add a singFarmSong() method that delegates to playFarmSong(). Ensure the signature is public void singFarmSong() so it matches the UML, the template, and any example/test invocations.
